Analyze a Programming Project as a Citations Network

vignette_analyse_citations_network_from_project.Rmd

This Vignette give a basic understanding of the corpus.list list of dataframes returned by codexplor::get_doc_network_from_project : a standard corpus.list with a citations network of functions within programming project(s).

codexplor::get_doc_network_from_project add a citations.network data.frameto the basic corpus.list returned by codexplor::construct_corpus.

The 1st matches of codexplor::construct_corpus let us find some files that defines a function, and the 2nd matches of compute_doc_network_from_corpus are the files that used these functions. Thus, links are beginning from the programming file that is calling a function => to the programming file where this function is defined.

You should start with the vignette of construct_corpus and then move to the vignette of the citations.network dataframe.

Example

Given folders path(s) and/or github repo(s), compute a citations network of the functions with 

    net <- get_doc_network_from_project(repos =  c("tidyverse/stringr", "clement-lvd/codexplor"))
    # by default, codexplor deal with R project

Then turn this edgelist into an interactive dataviz’ with networkD3 :

    get_networkd3_from_igraph(net$citations_network)
    # Return an interactive dataviz' from networkD3

By default, get_networkd3_from_igraph will colorize the nodes accordingly to their indegrees. This will reveal the local dependancies of the programming project (i.e. functions used by others files of the project).

.

(codexplor functions network is truncated) For example, the most-common local dependancy inside the tidyverse/stringr repo is compat-types-check.R, […] and we see that one of the codexplor file actually rely on a stringrmethod (i.e. codexplor::str_extract_all_to_tidy_df.R rely on stringr/extract.R). The opposite is not true.

Playing with the parameters will reveal others insights, e.g., you should try to color nodes accordingly to their outdegrees, in order to reveal the high-level files of the project.

Crafting your own corpus with codexplor

Depending on the languages you have to manage, you’ll want to tweak the ‘pattern’ used for match a function definition, since for now codexplor support only the R programming language (other languages are planned).
